intro: Amsinckia menziesii var. intermedia, commonly known as the desert mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its distinctive yellow flowers and soft, woolly foliage. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, such as deserts and rocky slopes, and is adapted to survive in low-water conditions. Its leaves are palmately lobed, and it produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small seeds. The plant is also known for its medicinal properties and has been used by indigenous peoples for various purposes.
